biogHist.abstract: St Vincent de Paul Orphanage was established by the Catholic Church in 1866 in Gilberton. In 1867 it took in Catholic children from the Grace Darling Hotel. The Orphanage moved to Adelaide in 1868, to Mitcham in 1872, Burnside in 1875 and Millswood in 1888. The Orphanage was run by the Orphanage Board from 1866 to 1872, The Sisters of St Joseph, 1872 to 1889 and the Sisters of Mercy, 1889 to 1975. Between 1949 and 1957, 54 migrant girls were brought to the Orphanage from England and Malta. The St Vincent de Paul Orphanage closed in 1975 and was replaced by a number of cottage homes known as the St Vincent Group Homes.
biogHist.p: The St Vincent de Paul Orphanage was first established by the Catholic Church in 1866. In the mid 1800s some members of the Catholic Church became concerned that orphans of the faith under government care were often placed with non-Catholic families. They believed that these children's spiritual welfare needed to be protected through the establishment of a Catholic orphanage. The orphanage was funded via a statewide appeal and a large house in Gilberton, known as Oberlin House, was secured for the purpose. Situated on the corner of Walkerville and Park Terraces, directly opposite the Buckingham Arms Hotel, the house had a large dining hall, two downstairs rooms for dormitories, two upstairs bedrooms and a large kitchen. There was also a paddock adjacent to the building, approximately one acre in size.

The Orphanage officially opened on 16 August 1866 and was managed by a board which included Catholic priests and laymen. A lay matron took charge of the first children sent to the Orphanage. A newspaper of the time reported the rules for the management of the Institution as follows:

'1. Children to rise from bed at 7o'clock a.m.; 2. Breakfast at 8 o'clock, an hour being allowed for washing, dressing, and prayer; 3. School to commence with prayer at 9.30 a.m., and to close also with prayer at 3 p.m. ; Dinner at 12 o'clock, the previous half-hour being allowed for play; 5. Supper to be served at 5 o'clock p.m. - young children allowed food when necessary; 6. Bed-hour (after prayer) for children of four years and over at 9 o'clock and 8 o'clock for those under that age; 7. Girls to be instructed in needlework, cookery, and other necessary domestic employment; 8. Boys to be employed at useful work, and to be carefully educated as to fit them for trades and other employment; 9. The matron shall neither receive nor allow any children to be taken out of the Orphanage unless by a written order from the Board signed by the Secretary; 10. Domestic servants and all others residing in the Orphanage to be strictly obedient to the command of the matron. '

In 1867 the government approached the Catholic Church and pressured them to give shelter to Catholic children from the badly overcrowded state orphanage situated at that time in the Grace Darling Hotel at Brighton. In May of that year the St Vincent de Paul Orphanage was gazetted as an industrial school so that the government could pay a subsidy for each child admitted. In the first half of 1867 thirty-eight children moved from Brighton to Walkerville. As the government sent more children to the Walkerville home, it was soon found to be too small for the demand. A building known as Boston Cottages on King William Street South was leased and opened as a branch orphanage for the girls. Children accommodated there, although under the direct care of a lay matron, were supervised by of the Sisters of St Joseph. In June 1868 the girls moved again to a row of cottages on the corner of Franklin and Grey Streets in the City. At this time a number of the Sisters moved in to care for them. The boys were also moved to these premises in August 1868.

During this period government sponsorship became intermittent and in 1872 ceased completely. However, the orphanage continued to run supported entirely by the church. In 1872 the children were moved from the City to a house in Mitcham, recently vacated by St Joseph's Refuge, which provided grounds as well as a building.

In November of 1872 the Orphanage Board ceased operating and the running of the Orphanage fell to the Sisters of St Joseph. Three years later, when the ownership of the Mitcham property changed hands, a larger premises known as Knightsbridge House was secured in Burnside and the children moved once again. In 1883 the Board was reconstituted as the Orphanage Committee, and they began the search for a more suitable property. This was found in 1888 and the children made their final move to a 12-13 acre (5 hectares) property secured by the Adelaide Archbishop on the corner of Mitchell Street and Goodwood Road, Millswood. The residence was renovated and new buildings added. One year later, by the order of Archbishop Reynolds, the Sisters of Mercy took over the running of the orphanage from the Sisters of St Joseph.
During the early 1900s further additions were made so that the home could accommodate up to 120 children. Another new wing was opened in 1924.

In 1947 the Archbishop of Adelaide, Archbishop Beovich, requested that 50 Catholic migrant English girls be brought to Adelaide to be accommodated at the St Vincent De Paul Orphanage. Renovations and improvements were made to the Orphanage buildings in order to accept the girls. The United Kingdom and Commonwealth Governments recognized St Vincent De Paul Orphanage, Goodwood, as an 'approved organisation' for the introduction of child migrants under the free and assisted passage schemes in August 1948. On 17 December 1948 twenty-eight girls between the ages of 6 and 14 years left England on the 'Ormonda'. They arrived at Port Adelaide and moved into the Orphanage on 19 January 1949. In May a further 14 girls arrived on the 'Mooltan', and in June 1950 four more on the Otranto. Although this fulfilled only 46 of the originally 50 girls that were to make up 'Group Nomination S.G. 10' it was later agreed that the nomination had been fulfilled.

In September 1950 Archbishop Beovich began negotiations for 12 Maltese girls to come to St Vincent De Paul Orphanage, Goodwood. It was not until April 1954, however, that the first 3 girls arrived from Malta aboard the 'Surriento'. In October of that year 3 more girls arrived aboard the 'Fairsea'. Only two more girls were sent from Malta, 1 arriving on the 'Arosa Star' in January 1955 and the last on the 'Castel Felice' in February 1955.

By 1960 ninety-nine children were resident in the orphanage. This number dropped to 52 in 1970 and at its closure in 1975, only 20 children were in residence. The role of St Vincent de Paul Orphanage was replaced by a number of suburban cottage homes know as the St Vincent Group Homes.

Address - St Vincent De Paul Orphanage was situated at Boston Cottages, King William Street South, Adelaide
Location - St Vincent De Paul Orphanage was situated at Franklin Street, Adelaide
Location - St Vincent De Paul Orphanage was situated at former premises of the St Joseph's Refuge, Mitcham
Location - St Vincent De Paul Orphanage was situated at Knightsbridge House, Burnside
Address - St Vincent De Paul Orphanage was situated at 181 Goodwood Road, on the corner of Mitchell Street, Millswood

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Sisters of St Joseph (1866 - )
Sisters of Mercy, Adelaide Congregation (1880 - 2011)
Brighton Industrial School (1867 - 1869)

descriptiveNote.p: Due to overcrowding at the Brighton Industrial School, a number of children were sent to the Catholic St Vincent de Paul's Orphanage and the Church of England's Orphan Home, also known as Farr House.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Children forwarded to the Roman Catholic Orphanage 1867-1869 (index) [Admission Register] (1867 - 1869)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by State Records of South Australia. This three page list names children sent from the Destitute Asylum to St Vincent de Paul Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: St Vincent de Paul Orphanage, Burnside [Admission Register] (1872 - 1889)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Professional Standards Office Records Service of the Catholic Church. This quarto sized hardcover notebook contains general admission information for children entering the Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Discharge Book, St Vincent de Paul Orphanage (1866 - 1920)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Professional Standards Office Records Service of the Catholic Church. This small hardback lined notebook contains information regarding the discharge of children from the Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: St Vincent de Paul Admission Register, Book 3 (labelled 3B) (1875 - 1975)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Professional Standards Office Records Service of the Catholic Church. This large ledger contains general admission information for children entering the Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: St Vincent de Paul Admission Register, Book 2 (1920 - 1949)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Professional Standards Office Records Service of the Catholic Church. This large handwritten and typed ledger contains general admission information for children entering the Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: St Vincent de Paul Admission Register, Book 1 (1875 - 1929)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Professional Standards Office Records Service of the Catholic Church. This large handwritten ledger contains general admission information for children entering the Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Admission forms, St Vincent de Paul Orphanage (1893 - 1895)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Professional Standards Office Records Service of the Catholic Church. This manilla folder contains some original admission forms and several handwritten agreements.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Records of St Vincent de Paul Orphanage (1866? - 1975?)
Admission list, St Vincent de Paul Orphanage (26 May 1941)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Professional Standards Office Records Service of the Catholic Church. This manilla folder contains a letter with an attached list of children in the Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Destitute Asylum (1851 - c. 1917)

descriptiveNote.p: Following the Destitute Persons Relief Act 1867, some children were moved from the Destitute Asylum to St Vincent de Paul Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: St Joseph's Junior Boys' Home (1960s - 1969)

descriptiveNote.p: While St Joseph's Junior Boys Home at Largs Bay took in boys between the ages of 3 and 12 all girls were sent to St Vincent de Paul Orphanage, Goodwood.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: St John the Baptist Home for Boys (1898 - 1941)

descriptiveNote.p: In 1941 St John the Baptist Home for Boys took boys aged 12 years of age or older, while younger boys were sent to the St Joseph's Orphanage at Largs Bay or to the St Vincent de Paul Orphanage at Goodwood.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Former Residents' Folders (1900s - )

descriptiveNote.p: The Former residents' folders, held by the Professional Standards Office, may contain information relating to St Vincent de Paul Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Photographs, St Vincent De Paul Orphanage (1866? - 1975?)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Adelaide Catholic Archdiocesan Archives. These photographs include a number of the Orphanage building.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: JD Somerville Oral History Collection (1904 - )
Stolen Generations
Inquiry into Children in Institutional Care (2003 - 2004)
St Joseph's Refuge (1868 - c. 2001)

descriptiveNote.p: St Vincent De Paul Orphanage was situated at former premises of the St Joseph's Refuge, Mitcham

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Records created by the Destitute Board (c. 1845 - 1927)
Records of St Vincent De Paul Orphanage (1866? - 1975?)
Records of St Vincent de Paul Orphanage (1866 - 1975)
Records held by the Sisters of St Joseph Archives (1866? - )
St Vincent de Paul Orphanage, Burnside [Admission Register] (1872 - 1883)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Professional Standards Office Records Service of the Catholic Church. This foolscap sized hardcover folder contains general admission information for children entering the Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Waverley Hostel (1972 - 1988)

descriptiveNote.p: Some girls from the St Vincent de Paul Orphanage were accommodated at Waverley Hostel after they left school and were seeking employment.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Children in State Care Commission of Inquiry, State of South Australia (2004 - 2008)
Child and Youth Migration to South Australia (1850s - c. 1981)
Child Migration - St Vincents de Paul Orphanage - Goodward, SA - Catholic (1947 - 1960)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the National Archives of Australia and available online. This file contains correspondence between St Vincent de Paul Orphanage, the Children's Welfare and Public Relief Board and the Commonwealth Department of Immigration regarding Child Migration.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Child Migration - Methodist Children's Home - Magill SA (1948 - 1955)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the National Archives of Australia and available online. This file contains correspondence between the Methodist Children's Home, the Children's Welfare and Public Relief Board and the Commonwealth Department of Immigration regarding Child Migration.It also contains references to St Vincent de Paul Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Goodwood Orphanage Oral History (1993 - 1994)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the State Library of South Australia as part of the JD Somerville Collection. This oral history is made up of seventeen interviews commissioned by the Libraries Board of SA concerning the experiences of children, nuns and priests living and working at St Vincent de Paul Orphanage, also known as Goodwood Orphanage. Please note this Oral History also includes an associated series of 72 photographs.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Miscellaneous records, St Vincent de Paul Orphanage (1890s - 1970s)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by The Adelaide Catholic Archdiocesan Archives. These miscellaneous records include correspondence, news clippings, early reports and other documents containing general and historical information related to the Orphanage.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Minutes, St Vincent de Paul Orphanage (1887 - 1890)

descriptiveNote.p: Held by the Professional Standards Office Records Service of the Catholic Church. This small hardback notebook contains minutes of meetings and includes some names of children and information about admissions.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: St Joseph's Orphanage Largs Bay (1907? - 1960s)

descriptiveNote.p: From 1941 all girls at St Joseph's Orphanage, Largs Bay, were sent to St Vincent de Paul Orphanage at Goodwood.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Orana Cottage Home, St Vincent de Paul Group Homes (1975 - 1980)
Bon Agor House, St Vincent de Paul Group Homes (1975 - 1989s)
Yoorana Cottage, St Vincent de Paul Group Homes (1975 - 1989)
